DataElement.preferredName: Breast Hormone Receptor Tumor Marker Diagnosis Result Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The outcome from pathological tests to determine presence of the hormone receptor in the nature of cancer by evaluating a sample of breast tissue.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Hormone Receptor Tumor Marker Final Diagnosis Result
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the last outcome from pathologic tests to determine presence and nature of cancer by evaluating breast tissue for ligand binding proteins (hormones) present in or produced by tumor.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:Ligand binding proteins that bind signalling molecules external to the cell with high affinity and convert this extracellular event into one or more intracellular signals that alter the behavior of the target cell.  The hormone receptor can be cytoplasmic/nuclear, or associated with the cell membrane in the case of receptors whose ligands cannot penetrate the membrane.:A substance sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood, other body fluids, or tissues and which may mean that a certain type of cancer is in the body. Examples of tumor markers include CA 125 (ovarian cancer), CA 15-3 (breast cancer), CEA (ovarian, lung, breast, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract cancers), and PSA (prostate cancer). Also called biomarker.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Ligand binding proteins that bind signalling molecules external to the cell with high affinity and convert this extracellular event into one or more intracellular signals that alter the behavior of the target cell.  The hormone receptor can be cytoplasmic/nuclear, or associated with the cell membrane in the case of receptors whose ligands cannot penetrate the membrane.

A substance present in or produced by a tumor or by the host, that can be used for differentiating neoplastic from normal tissue based on measurements in body fluids, secretions, cells, and/or tissues. Markers are used in diagnosis, staging and prognosis of cancer, provide an estimation of tumor burden, and serve for monitoring effects of therapy, detecting recurrence, localization of tumors, and screening in general populations.

Property.preferredDefinition: Conclusive in a process or progression.:The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.:Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: Conclusive in a process or progression.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: Tumor Marker Pathology Diagnosis Result Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the outcome reported from pathologic tests to determine presence and nature of cancer by evaluating a sample of tissue for substances present in or produced by tumor.

PermissibleValues.value: Estrogen Receptor Positive And Progesterone Receptor Positive
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Estrogen Receptor Positive And Progesterone Receptor Positive

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Estrogen Receptor Positive And Progesterone Receptor Positive
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that have a receptor protein that binds the hormone estrogen. Cancer cells that are estrogen receptor positive may need estrogen to grow, and may stop growing or die when treated with substances that block the binding and actions of estrogen.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: Describes cells that have a protein to which the hormone progesterone will bind. Cancer cells that are progesterone receptor positive need progesterone to grow and will usually stop growing when treated with hormones that block progesterone from binding.

Concepts.definition: An indication that estrogen receptor alpha expression has been detected in a sample.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
An indication that progesterone receptor (PRG; PR) expression has been detected in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that do not have a protein to which the hormone progesterone will bind. Cancer cells that are progesterone receptor negative do not need progesterone to grow, and usually do not stop growing when treated with hormones that block progesterone from binding.

Concepts.definition: An indication that progesterone receptor (PRG; PR) expression has not been detected in a sample.

PermissibleValues.value: Estrogen Receptor Negative and Progesterone Receptor Negative
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Estrogen Receptor Negative And Progesterone Receptor Negative

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Estrogen Receptor Negative And Progesterone Receptor Negative
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that do not have a protein to which the hormone estrogen will bind. Cancer cells that are estrogen receptor negative do not need estrogen to grow, and usually do not stop growing when treated with hormones that block estrogen from binding.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: Describes cells that do not have a protein to which the hormone progesterone will bind. Cancer cells that are progesterone receptor negative do not need progesterone to grow, and usually do not stop growing when treated with hormones that block progesterone from binding.

Concepts.definition: The absence of detectable estrogen receptor alpha in a tissue sample.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
An indication that progesterone receptor (PRG; PR) expression has not been detected in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that do not have a protein to which the hormone estrogen will bind. Cancer cells that are estrogen receptor negative do not need estrogen to grow, and usually do not stop growing when treated with hormones that block estrogen from binding.

Concepts.definition: The absence of detectable estrogen receptor alpha in a tissue sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that have a protein to which the hormone progesterone will bind. Cancer cells that are progesterone receptor positive need progesterone to grow and will usually stop growing when treated with hormones that block progesterone from binding.

Concepts.definition: An indication that progesterone receptor (PRG; PR) expression has been detected in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes cells that have a receptor protein that binds the hormone estrogen. Cancer cells that are estrogen receptor positive may need estrogen to grow, and may stop growing or die when treated with substances that block the binding and actions of estrogen.

Concepts.definition: An indication that estrogen receptor alpha expression has been detected in a sample.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
